trans-unit.source: Provides a base class for all ASP.NET mobile control classes.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
As the base class for all ASP.NET mobile controls, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl> class primarily contains style and context information common to all controls.
For more information about style and context information, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> classes.

Because this class derives from the ASP.NET <xref:System.Web.UI.Control> base class, all <xref:System.Web.UI.Control> base class properties, methods, and events are available in each of the mobile controls.
Initializes the class for use by an inherited class instance.
This constructor can only be called by an inherited class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Returns the device-specific adapter for the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.IControlAdapter> instance returned is specific to the current <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl> object.
Any child controls of the current control will use their specific adapter as well.
An adapter specific to the device on which the page will be displayed, which is also usually specific to the control.
Called after a child control is added to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Controls"></xref> collection of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> object.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> that has been added.
The index of the control in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Controls"></xref> collection.
Adds the set of forms that contains links to the specified control to the provided list.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When a form contains navigation elements that activate another form without interaction from the server, it is considered a linked form.
There are several criteria for a form to be considered linked.
For example, if the following three conditions are met, Form B is considered to be linked to Form A:
Form A contains a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> with its destination as Form B.
Form A does not contain an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnDeactivate%2A> event handler.
Form B has no <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnActivate%2A> event handler.
The base implementation does nothing, but other controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link>, override the default implementation.
The set of forms that contain links to the specified control.
Notifies the server control that an element, either XML or HTML, was parsed, and adds the element to the server control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.ControlCollection"></xref> object.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that represents the parsed element.
Gets or sets the specified alignment for the style.
The default value is <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Alignment.NotSet"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.Alignment%2A> property can be set to any of the following values.
Value
Description
No alignment is set for the specified object.
Aligns to the left.
Aligns to the center.
Aligns to the right.
An enumerated value specifying the alignment for the style.
Applies the style properties defined in the page style sheet to the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl> class does not support theming.
If an attempt to call the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.ApplyStyleSheetSkin%2A> method is made, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.Page"></xref> containing the control.
In all cases.
Gets or sets the specified background color for the style.
The default value is <xref href="System.Drawing.Color.Empty"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Unlike the other properties, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.BackColor%2A> property is not inherited from its parent.

For example, if you set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.BackColor%2A> property to cyan on a parent control, a child control will not inherit a background color of cyan; you must explicitly set the child control's <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.BackColor%2A> property to cyan, or you must set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.BackColor%2A> property of the parent control and apply the style sheet to the child control.
This is consistent with the behavior of cascading style sheets.
The specified background color for the style.
Gets or sets a property that determines whether an additional trailing break is rendered after the control.
This break causes subsequent content to start on the next line.
The default is `true`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Do not set this property to `true` on a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control.
If you set this property to `true`, the control will throw an exception.
This property is ignored by controls for which a trailing break does not make sense.
The following table lists the controls that support the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.BreakAfter%2A> property for certain kinds of devices.
The following table shows the controls with the types of devices that support the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.BreakAfter%2A> property.
Check with device manufacturers to determine the effects of this property on their devices.
Control
Device With HTML Browser
Device With WML Browser
Device with WML/UP Browser
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes (unless device's browser can handle tables)
`Panel` (default is false)
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes (Unless browser can handle tables)
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
`true` if an additional trailing break is rendered after the control; otherwise, `false`.
Called by device adapters to create the default templated user interface (UI) for the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Set to `true` if the instantiated templates must bind to available data (which usually happens on the first request).
Set to `false` if the templates must not bind to data, and instead rely on view state to fill them in (which usually happens on subsequent postbacks).
Constructs and returns the style object to be associated with the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Inheriting classes can override this method to return a more specific style class.
The style object to be associated with the control.
Called by base classes to create a templated UI.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The default implementation calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.CreateTemplatedUI%2A> method of the corresponding control adapter, which can in turn call back the control's <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.CreateDefaultTemplatedUI%2A> method or create its own device-specific templated UI.
Returns `true` if the instantiated templates bind to available data (which usually happens on the first request).
Returns `false` if the templates do not bind to data, and instead rely on view state to fill them in (which usually happens on subsequent postbacks).
Returns the set of custom attributes defined for the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
You must set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.AllowCustomAttributes%2A> to `true` to enable custom attributes.
The set of custom attributes defined for the control.
Gets or sets the DeviceSpecific/Choice construct associated with the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The DeviceSpecific/Choice construct associated with the control, or `null` if no such construct exists.
Gets a value indicating whether themes apply to this control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl> class does not support theming.
If an attempt to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.EnableTheming%2A> property is made, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> exception is thrown.
`False` in all cases.
An attempt to set the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.EnableTheming"></xref> property is made.
Use this method to ensure that the templates are instantiated to allow programmatic access to the instantiated contents of a template.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method is overridden by the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.List> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList> classes.
Returns the first page of the form on which this control appears.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is used for form pagination.
The first page of the form on which this control appears.
Gets a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.FontInfo"></xref> object that contains font information about the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.FontInfo> class has the following properties.
Property
Description
The font is bold.
The font is italic.
An identifier for this font instance.
The font size.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.FontInfo"></xref> that contains the font information about the control.
Gets or sets the specified foreground color for the style.
Typically, this property sets the color for the text.
The default value is <xref href="System.Drawing.Color.Empty"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.ForeColor%2A> property to display text in different colors for all the controls and classes listed in the Inheritance section that follows.

For example, in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.AdRotator>, setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.ForeColor%2A> property changes the color of the text in the control; in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Calendar>, it changes the color of the text in the calendar; and in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ValidationSummary>, it changes the color of the text of the error messages.
The strings that can be used for colors are a set of fixed colors and hexadecimal RGB values.
These values can also be specified in the form "#RRGGBB."
For example, "#bb7023".
You can also use the Microsoft Windows color constants.
For specific details, see <xref:System.Drawing.SystemColors>.
The specified foreground color for the style.
Provides access to the containing form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The form that contains this control.
the control is not in a form as required.

The only mobile controls not required to be in a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form"></xref> are a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form"></xref> and a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.StyleSheet"></xref>.
Retrieves the specified attribute property from the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.GetAttribute%2A> method returns attributes stored in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.CustomAttributes%2A> property.
If <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.CustomAttributes%2A> is `null`, then <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.GetAttribute%2A> will also return `null`.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that specifies the name of the server control attribute.
A representing the value of the specified attribute; if no attribute with the specified name exists, then `null`.
Returns the template with the specified name.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Returns `null` if the control is not templated, or if the template does not exist in the selected template set.
The name of the specified template.
The template with the specified name.
Returns the text inside the control.
The inner text might be a combination of text from child controls.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text inside the control.
the inner text contains markup tags at run time, and the derived control does not allow markup tags in inner text.
the value used to set this property contains new line characters and the derived control does not allow multiple lines of text.
Returns `true` if the control submits the form.
The default is `false`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Mobile controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command>, can override this method to determine whether this is a control used for form submission.
Other controls can be extended by providing logic to programmatically determine whether or not they must be `submit` controls, for example, by checking for specific properties.
A control is considered to be a form-submit control only if it implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> method to capture the postback event.
Otherwise, it is not registered for the default event handler, even if the method returns `true`.
`true` if the control submits the form; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value indicating whether a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl"></xref> object has an active template set.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

To be considered templated, an object must have a [\<DeviceSpecific> element](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/5984e67a-91cf-4f32-8815-7e7fab3d3b5b) with a [\<Choice> element](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/c81bee77-bb45-4211-be0f-e13a040b3c2d) successfully evaluated for the target device.
The selected choice must have templates defined.
`true` if the control has an active template set; otherwise, `false`.
Returns whether or not the control is visible on the given page of the form.
Used for form pagination.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The page number.
`true` if the control is visible on the given page of the form; otherwise, `false`.
Returns the last page of the form on which the specified control is displayed.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is used for form pagination.
The last page of the form on which the specified control is displayed.
Loads private view state.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Current view state of the control.
Restores view-state information from a previous page request that was saved by the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.SaveViewState"></xref> method.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that represents the control state to be restored.
Returns the containing page.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is similar to the Web Forms <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Page%2A> property except that it is strongly typed.
The containing page.
the control is not in a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage"></xref>.
(Only occurs at run time.)
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Init"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Unload"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method notifies the server control that it should perform actions common to each HTTP request for the page it is associated with, such as setting up a database query.
At this stage in the page lifecycle, server controls in the hierarchy are created and initialized, view state is restored, and form controls reflect client-side data.
Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.IsPostBack%2A> property to determine whether the page is being loaded in response to a client postback, or if it is being loaded and accessed for the first time.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
the control contains custom attributes and the current page does not allow custom attributes on controls.
Paginates a control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When all the contents of a control cannot be displayed on the browsing device's screen at once, this function is called to paginate the control.
The index numbers are zero-based.
Contains the index number of the current page prior to pagination.
Contains the index number of the current page after pagination.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains the event data.
Renders a control to the specified output stream.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> that will render the content.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Unload"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains event data.
Gets a value that indicates whether the children of the control must be paginated.
Used for form pagination.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
`true` if the children of the control must be paginated; otherwise, `false`.
Paginates the control and its children.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The pager.
Called after a child control is removed from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Controls"></xref> collection of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> object.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control"></xref> that has been removed.
Sends server control content to a provided <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> object, which writes the content to be rendered on the client.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> object that receives the server control content.
Outputs the content of a server control's child controls using the provided <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method iterates through the child controls and renders each control.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> object that receives the rendered content.
Returns the form object referenced by the name parameter.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If you have a link of the format "#form1" in a control contained in a user control, this method looks for a form with `id=form1` in the user control.
If not found, it goes up the chain of any nested user controls, and then searches for the form on the page.
Scoping rules walk up, not down, the chain.
If you want to browse to a form that is contained in a user control, you must use the ":" syntax used by <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.FindControl%2A> method to refer to the form.
Form object
The form referenced by the name parameter.
formID does not refer to an existing .
Converts a URL into one that is usable on the requesting client.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The URL to be resolved.
The value of the specified URL.
Saves any private view-state changes that have occurred since the page was loaded from persistence.
If no changes were made, this method returns `null`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
You can override this method to store a private view state.
In addition to information saved with the ordinary view state, ASP.NET mobile Web Forms store information such as whether or not the form is paginated.
This added information is stored in the private view state and is stored on the client rather than the server.
A private view state is saved in an optimized manner.
Default behavior, such as making the first form the active form, is never included in the saved private view state.
An object containing the altered private view state.
Saves any server control view-state changes that have occurred since the time the page was posted back to the server.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Returns the server control's current view state.
If there is no view state associated with the control, this method returns `null`.
Designates an attribute and its value to assign to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl"></xref> object.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The attributes set through calls to the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.SetAttribute%2A> method are stored in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.CustomAttributes%2A> property.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> signifying the key of the attribute to be set.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> to be assigned as the value of the attribute.
Gets the ID of the skin to apply to the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl> class does not support theming.
If an attempt to set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.SkinID%2A> property is made, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> exception is thrown.
An empty <xref href="System.String"></xref> object.
An attempt to set the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.SkinID"></xref> property is made.
Gets the style of the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The style of the control.
Gets or sets a reference to the style properties for a control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.StyleReference%2A> property must be the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Style.Name%2A> property of a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Style> object.

You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.StyleReference%2A> property to share styles across controls, either by using inheritance or by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.StyleReference%2A> property of a style sheet.
For more information, see the Styles documentation.
To find out how to create a new style, see [Creating New Styles](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/da7f9825-3cc7-4c0f-9800-7d3cb15041d1).
A reference to the style properties for a control.
Causes tracking of view-state changes to the server control so they can be stored in the server control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.ViewState"></xref> property.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets the approximate weight of the control, in characters.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is used for form pagination.
A value of -1 indicates that the default weight for the element must be used.
For further information, see [Pagination Support](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/78f2786d-0b5b-4760-9616-5027357713c2).
The approximate weight of the control, in characters.
Gets or sets the specified wrapping mode for the style.
The default value is <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Wrapping.NotSet"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The following table contains the definitions of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Wrapping> enumeration.
Enumerations
Value
Description
No size is set for the specified object.
This is the default value.
Wrap to the next line.
The text is not wrapped to the next line.
An enumerated value that specifies the wrapping mode for the style.
